title: Jurgen Klopp fumes at controversial VAR use on day when 'everything went against' Liverpool
text:
Jurgen Klopp criticised VAR and Manchester United’s defensive tactics after Liverpool needed a late equaliser to salvage their unbeaten start at Old Trafford.

Klopp was angry that Marcus Rashford’s goal was allowed to stand after referee Martin Atkinson refused to give Liverpool a foul for Victor Lindelof’s challenge on Divock Origi in the build-up.

VAR backed Atkinson’s decision and was then used to rule out Sadio Mane’s effort before half-time for handball when he tangled with Lindelof before scoring.

Liverpool felt they should have been awarded a free kick for a foul on Divock Origi on Sunday

Martin Atkinson did not give it and Manchester United countered and scored the opening goal

Even though substitute Adam Lallana equalised five minutes from the end of normal time, Klopp couldn’t hide his frustration.

‘I was 100 per cent sure VAR would overrule it,’ said the Liverpool boss.

‘But now we see the problem. The ref let the game run because he has VAR, but VAR then says it was not clear so they don’t overrule it. That doesn’t make too much sense.

‘It’s just wow. I saw it was a foul and nothing else. Mr Atkinson I’m sure would have whistled if there was no VAR involved, but now we have somebody else who can make the decision. But somebody else is not making the decision.

‘Like the penalty Manchester City did not get yesterday (against Crystal Palace). Come on, that is 100 per cent a penalty. Not clear enough to overrule? They sit in the studio, they see it. Just take it away.

‘Pretty much everything went against us. Like our goal, eh? I heard that both players were there with the hand, but the other one is first then it should have been allowed.’ However, United boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer insisted it was not a foul by Lindelof and it was right to allow the goal.

Liverpool manager vented his frustrations with the decision at the time with Jon Moss

‘No chance, we’re not playing basketball,’ said Solskjaer. ‘He touched him but it’s not a clear and obvious error.

‘I think it was a slight touch but it’s still a man’s game with tackles allowed. That (the handball) was a clear one from Mane. We were on the right end of the VAR decisions.’ The Sky Sports pundits disagreed including former United defender Gary Neville.

‘I thought it was a foul,’ said Neville. ‘They’ve set the bar so high that we’re not going to see it change now, and they’re backed into a corner. I always think the measure is if it’s against my team, and if that was against United I’d want a foul.’

Graeme Souness: ‘Any way you look at it, if you’re kicked from behind, there’s a foul. He doesn’t get anything on the ball and I think they’ve got that wrong.

The German coach vented his frustrations after the game with how VAR technology is used

‘What influences them is that Origi goes down spectacularly. He has a poor first touch, the ball has gone away from him, he’s lost possession and I think he overeggs it with the way he goes down.’ Klopp was also unhappy over United’s tactics as Solskjaer played with five at the back and looked to hit Liverpool on the break.

United had 32.1 per cent possession, their second lowest in a Premier League game at home since the 2003-04 season, and Klopp said: ‘They were set out to defend us. We should have done better, but it’s the easy thing to do to set up like this.

‘When I’m England Man United pretty much set up like this. Everyone built it up like a mountain, but one team set out to defend and one team made the game.’ Jose Mourinho, who was in charge when United only had 32.0 per cent possession in March 2018, had no sympathy for the German.

Klopp also criticised how Manchester United approached the game on Sunday afternoon

Jose Mourinho slammed Klopp after Liverpool boss criticised United for their defensive tactics

Mourinho told Sky Sports: ‘He [Klopp] didn’t like the menu. He likes meat and he got fish.

‘United, with the limitations they have at the moment, they played with five at the back, were solid and didn’t give the chance of transition. Jurgen Klopp didn’t like the menu.

‘Liverpool missed quality to play against a team with a low block. They have a fantastic record of so many victories. But they have limitations against teams with low blocks. They can smash opponents that play the way they want to play against.

‘Jurgen clearly has frustrations. It’s a fantastic situation for his team. But at Old Trafford - which is a special place to win - he never did it.’
description: Klopp was angry that Marcus Rashford's goal was allowed to stand after referee Martin Atkinson refused to give Liverpool a foul for Victor Lindelof's challenge on Divock Origi in the build-up.
authors: Chris Wheeler For The Daily Mail
